cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.

WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1904.

div.head: PORT OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The present congested condition of the port of Alexandria is giving rise to numerous and well-founded complaints, loudest among which is perhaps that of the shipowners whose vessels are in the timber-carrying trade. As we stated recently, the Swedish and Norwegian Diplomatic Agent has approached the Government on the subject, which certainly deserves the most serious attention on their part. The state of affairs prevailing on the quays, and which has lasted for some time past (since July we believe), is little short of scandalous, and we have been at pains to enquire into the matter. We find that timber-laden ships have in some instances been kept at the buoys for a matter of 30 to 40 days before they could get alongside the quays in order to discharge their cargoes, and even then they have been kept waiting an inordinate length of time owing to the lack of storage accommodation and transport facilities.

The fault seems to lie in a great measure with the importers, who have taken advantage of favourable circumstances in the buying mar ket to force their imports, knowing full well that it would be impossible to cope with the number of cargoes on arrival here. These mer chants, on the other hand, contend that they warned the authorities years ago that in 1904 they might expect a considerable accretion in the amount of timber imported into the country. However that may be, the fact remains that ships are kept lying in the harbour for wedka without being able to unload, and a remedy for this state of things is urgently needed. In a peti. tion which was addressed a little time back to the Swedish and Norwegian Diplomatic Agent by the captains of timber vessels in the port, the latter maintained that ships could be dis charged more expeditiously than was being done. They adduced in support of their asser tion the case of the S.S. Massilisburg, which had discharged a quantity of about 650 stan dards between Saturday afternoon and Tuesday at 2 p.m on the Russian quay. On the other hand, in a period of three weeks, a very small proportion of that quantity had been discharged by other vessels at the usual timber quays. The whole of the Massilisburg's cargo was removed from the quay in the same time that it took to discharge, which proves that when an effort is made it is possible to expedite transport as well.

The masters of vessels charge importers with using their ships as warehouses. The quays are blocked and the merchants' sheds are as full as they can be. It is obviously unfair, therefore, if merchants have ordered more goods than they can conveniently handle, that the shipowners, who have great interests at stake, should suffer in consequence. We see no reason why the merchants should not be compelled to remove cargoes from the quays without delay. If they have no storage accommodation that is their lookout. It is surely possible for them to hire -open spaces outside the city for the purpose. According to regulations, we under stand that the authorities can clear the quays themselves if it is proved that merchants deliberately block them. There are at present twelve timber-laden ships in the harbour waiting to be discharged and several more are on the way. What the condition of the quays will be when they arrive it. is impossible to conceive.

The shipping companies are practically powerless, but several cases of demurrage are coming before the Mixed Courts shortly, and we believe that the shipowners have declared war against the merchants. The principle which applies in England, and which will probably be found to apply here as well, is that if it can be proved that shippers have recklessly and wilfully chartered such an amount of tonnage as of necessity would cause a glut of tonnage and consequent delay to chartered ships, redress may be had.

div.p: TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS.

div.head: PORT ARTHUR
div.p: A BOMBARDMENT. SHIPS ON FIRE.

CHI-FU, December 6. The Japanese, who are steadily bombarding the fleet from the 203 metre hill, set fire to two or three warships during the evening of the 4th inst. The names of the vessels and the extent of the damage are unknown. (Reuter.)
TOKIO, December 6.

(Official). The bombardment at Port Arthur caused the explosion of a magazine south of Faiu-shan on the 3rd inst. The operations against the Sung-shu-shan fort and the forts eastwards are proceeding day and night. Two 36-millemetre quick-firing guns were captured on Sunday in the lunette and centrescarp of Erhlung-shan fort.
The Russian are nightly attacking the 203 metre hill, but without success. It is estimated ey have already sacrificed 3,000 men in these efforts to recapture the position. (R.)

div.head: MANCHURIA.
div.p: GENERAL SITUATION
UNALTERED.
MANY CASES OF ILLNESS.

MURDEN, December 6. A four days' artillery duel on the centre and right has failed to alter the general situation. There is considerable illness in consequence of the close confinement in the trenches and bomb-proofs, and the continual nervous strain. (Reuter.)

div.head: GENERAL NEWS..
div.p: YARFOW DESTROYER INCIDENT.
TWO ENGLISHMEN
IMPLICATED.
LONDON, December 6.
Summonses have been issued against two Englishmen-Messrs. Sinnett and Roche-who were instrumental in purchasing the Yarrow destroyer. Both gentlemen are in Paris. (R.)

div.head: BREAD RIOTS IN RUSSIA. ACCOMPANIED BY BLOODSHED.
div.p: LONDON, December 6.

The Standard learns from Moscow that, in consequence of the high prices of food, following on the war, there have been bread riots with bloodshed in many of the districts. At Dunaberg the soldiers participated in the looting. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE AFGHAN FRONTIER. DESPATCH OF RUSSIAN TROOPS.
div.p: LONDON, December 6.
The military division stationed in the Caucasus district is under orders to proceed to
the Afghan frontier.
(Reuter.)

div.head: GREAT BRITAIN AND GERMANY.
div.p: COUNT VON BULOW'S STATEMENTS.
BERLIN, December 6.

Count von Bülow, in the Reichstag, repu- diated the assertions of Herr Bebel, and said that the object of the interview in the Nineteenth Century was to extirpate the weeds which British journalists had been sowing in the field of German politics. No sensible people could wish for war between Great Britain and Germany. (Reuter.)

div.head: GERMAN MISSION TO ABYSSINIA. LEAVING THIS MONTH.
div.p: BERLIN, December 6.
A commercial mission, headed by a high Foreign Office official, will proceed to Abyssinia during December. (Reuter.)
ANGLO-FRENCH CONVENTION. CRITICISM IN THE SENATE.
PARIS, December 6.

During the debate on the Anglo-French Convention in the Senate, M. de Caverville condemned the clauses concerning Egypt. He asked for the rejection of the convention. M. Daumay criticised the abandonment of the financial control in Egypt, but congratulated the Government on the agreement relating to Morocco. (Havas.)
JAURES-DERGULEDE DUEL.
HENDAYE, December 5.
M.M. Jaurès nd Déroulède exchanged two shots without an; result. (Havas.)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: SHIPS COMING TO SUEZ.
TANGIER, December 6.
The cruisers Oleg and Izumrud, the vanguard of Admiral Botrovosky's supplementary Baltic
Fieet, have left for Suez.
(Reuter.)
ALGIERS, December 6.
The Rion (formerly the Smolensk) and two
destroyers have arrived here.
(Reuter.)

div.head: NORTH SEA INCIDENT.
div.p: A BELATED STATEMENT.
RUSSIANS FIRE ON THEMSELVES.
ST. PETERSBURG, December 6.

The Naval Headquarters announce that supplementary information received from Ad- miral Rodjestvensky regarding the North Sea incident states that the "cease fire" was signalled ten minutes after the commencement, in order to prevent the hindermost vessels of the squadron from hitting their own ships. The cruiser Aurora was struck by five projectiles.. The chaplain and a petty officer were wounded. The former died at Tangier. (Reuters)
LONDON, December 6. The English papers regard Admiral Rodjest- vensky's belated statement, which is some- what obscurely worded, as virtually admitting that the Russians fired on one another. (R.)

div.head: MESSAGE TO CONGRESS.
div.p: PRESIDENT AND DISARMAMENT.
TRADE IN ASIA.
WASHINGTON, December 6.

President Roosevelt, in his Message to Congress, says that the steady aim of the United States should be to strive to hasten the reign of peace and justice, but they must be supported by the necessary force. It would be wicked for the civilised nations to disarm at present, as such a step would result in a recrudescence of barbarism.
Mr. Roosevelt earnestly recommends the building up of the navy. He cites the lessons of the present war as showing that the main reliance of a navy must be in its great battle- ships.

He dwells on the undiminished importance of enlarging trade in Asia, and suggests the permanent display of American products in a prominent centre in China, with a view to advancing the export trade. With reference to tariffs, Mr. Roosevelt will communicate with Congress later. (Reuters)

div.head: DEATH OF LORD HOBHOUSE.
div.p: LONDON, December 6.
Lord Hobhouse is dead.
(Reuter.)

div.head: A COTILLON BALL
div.p: will be given at Shepheard's Hotel on January 4, for which 300 invitations will be issued.

div.head: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION. -
div.p: Al Ahram states that the Customs Administration will be transferred to Cairo at the beginning of next year.

div.head: SANITARY DEPARTMENT.-
div.p: Dr. Charles Max- well Hickens has been appointed sub-inspector to the Sanitary Administration at a salary of L.E. 360 per annum.

div.head: BRACALE ORCHESTRA.-
div.p: Maestro Bracale has engaged M. Arrigo Serato, the celebrated violinist, to give a few concerts at Alexandria and Cairo.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE'S PORTRAIT.-
div.p: His Highness the Khedive has commissioned Mr. J. Watson Nicol and given sittings for a full-length life-size portrait in oils. Mr. Nicol is a member of the Society of Oil Painters.

div.head: THE DANTE ALIGHIERI SOCIETY
div.p: at Alex- andria last month opened a free evening school. The curriculum will embrace a general course of elementary instruction. The classes aref greatly appreciated and are already attended by numerous students.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.-
div.p: 28 vessels passed through the Canal on the 3rd and 4th inst., the receipts for the two days being frs. 732,768.81. Of the ships 21 were British, 2 French, 1. Austrian, 2 German, and 2 Dutch. The total receipts from the 1st to 4th inst. were frs. 1,530,805.60 from 59 vessels.

div.head: P. O. SAVINGS BANK.-
div.p: The amount of depo- sits in the P. O. Savings Bank during the month of November was L.E. 23,087, bringing the total amount deposited up to L.E. 195,728. The sums withdrawn during the month amounted to L.E. 19,231. The number of depositors now amounts to 28.519.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive will probably pay a visit to Montazah on Saturday next. His Highness will return to Koubbeh Palace on the Wednes- day following.
The third list of subscriptions for the Khedivial Accession Fête shows a total of L.E. 360.

div.head: BEYRAM.
div.p: To-morrow being the first day of Beyram, the 16th Infantry Battalion and the Cavalry Band will pay the honours to the Diplomatic Corps on their arrival at Abdeen Palace to visit H. H. the Khedive.

A salute of 21 guns will be fired in the morning as the Khedive leaves the Koubbeh Mosque. The usual salutes will be fired from the Citadel, at Abbassieh, at Alexandria, and at Port Said on the eve and during the three days of Beyram.

div.head: FASHIONABLE WEDDING
div.p: MACPHERSON-GRANT- MACCALLUM.

St. Peter's Church, Eaton-square, London, was Monday week the scene of the wedding of the Agent for the Sudan Government Railway at Alexandria, Mr. George B. Macpherson-Grant, son of Sir George and Lady Macpherson-Grant, of Ballindalloch, and Miss Dorothy Eleanor Kellie MacCallum. Mr. Douglas Brodie, of Brodie, was best man. Lady Macdonald of the Isles, the Hon. Ione Macdonald, Edith Lady Auckland, Lady Charlotte Legge, Lady Octavia Legge, Lady Wilhelmina Brooke and Miss Brooke, Lady Willoughby, the Hon. Mrs. E. Cecil, the Hon. Mrs. Drummond, Lady Lysons, Miss Brodie of Brodie, and Sir John Edwardes Moss were among the invited guests.

The father of the bride is Mr. J. D. Kellie MacCallum, formerly in the 79th (Queen's Own) Cameron Highlanders, and now Chief Consta ble of Northamptonshire. The ceremony was conducted by the Rev. Prebendary Storrs, Vi- car of St. Peter's Church, assisted by the Rev. A. B. Polwhele, Rector of Quinton. Five maids were in attendance on the bride, who was mar- ried in a robe of flowing silvery white satin, the bodice being trimmed with old family Carrick- macross lace, silver embroidery, and bunches of white Scotch heather and jasmine, while the veil was worn over a tiara of orange-blossoms. Afterwards Mr. and Mrs. G. B. Macpherson- Grant left for Ballindalloch Castle.

div.head: PUBLIC WORKS.
div.p: The annual embankment works in the canals, dykes, and drains of the provinces of Keneh and Assouan have been adjudicated as follows:-Nag Hamadi, Moh. Tandi; Dedinos Mr. Wakefield; Keneh, Urquhart and William- son; Kous (East), Cumming and Logan; Kous (West), Soliman Hamoud; Esneh, Alessan- drini and Buccianti; Assouan and Edfou, Ezzeddin Mohamed, Sefi canals of Nag Ha madi, Société d'Irrigation.

div.head: EXPORT OF GUM ARABIC.
div.p: During the month of October last, 892,954 kilos of gum arabic, valued at L.E. 20,093, were exported from Egypt. In the same month of 1903 the exports were 905,135 kilos, of the value of L.E. 20,322, showing a decrease this year of 64 kilos, value L.E. 149.

From the 1st January to 31st October 1904. the exports show increases of 1,399,811 kilos in weight and of L.E. 28,158 in amount as compared with last year, the respective figures being as follows: 1904, 8,507,197 kilos, value L.E. 191,431; 1903, 7,107,386 kilos, value L.E. 163,273.

Of the above, the export to England and her Mediterranean possessions was 1,363,802 kilos, value L.E. 30,685; Germany, 1,408,631 kilos, value L.E. 31,695; Austria-Hungary, 623,663 kilos, value L.E. 14,030; France and Algeria, 2,437,359 kilos, value L.E. 54,838; Italy, 220,661 kilos, value L.E. 4,982; Turkey, 11,921 kilos, value L.E. 260; America, 1,309,545 kilos, value L.E. 29,464, and to other countries 1,131,614 kilos, value L.E. 25,497.

div.head: PROGRESS AT ALEXANDRIA,
div.p: ICE AND COLD STORAGE.

Many of our readers will remember the great difficulty we had during last summer in Alex- andria to obtain a supply of ice. For some reason or other, the local ice-works entirely failed to produce a proper supply, and for a long time more than half of the ice sold in the town was brought either from Cairo or Tantah and the price we had to pay for it was very high. To the native population, who use a con- siderable amount of ice, it is more of a luxury; but to Europeans who have to pass the summer here, it is almost a necessity, and unless certain articles of food and drink can be kept cool artificially, it is often difficult to tempt the jaded appetite during the hottest months. It is therefore essential to our well- being that there should be a good supply of ice, and at a reasonable price. We are glad to find that this want is likely to be met in the future, for already several firms or companies are preparing to erect new works, and we have reason to hope that not only will the supply be equal to the demand, but that competition will bring the usual result, and that there will be a considerable reduction in the price we have hitherto paid.

We hear, too, that attention is being given to another important question, that of cold storage, which has had such a large develop- ment in Europe and, to a greater extent, in America. We all know how difficult it is here to obtain meat that is tender, because it has to be eaten so soon after it is killed; if it could be kept for a few days in cold storage it would become tender and much more wholesome. The butchers often sustain much loss by having to get rid of their meat in so short a time, and this tends to increase the price. The same argument applies to fish, fruit, and many other commodities. Game is brought here in small quantities from Cyprus, Asia Minor, Italy, Austria, and other places, but it is very dear, and has to be got rid of immediately on its arrival. With proper means for cold storage, this trade would considerably increase, and prices would become much more reasonable. In many ways cold storage will be a benefit, and it will put within the reach of people of moder- ate means, advantages which have hitherto been available only to the much smaller class of wealthy people. We are glad to hear that, among others, the Alexandria Water Company is taking up this question, and will probably before long erect both ice-works and cold storage. It appears to us that this company should be in a position to carry out such work economically, and to offer these commodities to the town at a very reasonable rate, as well as to ensure a more constant supply than we have had to put up with in recent years.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA NAPLES MARSEILLES SERVICE
div.p: We understand that the Norddeutscher Lloyd Steam Navigation Co. has decided to make the fortnightly service from Alexandria to Na- ples and Marseilles, at present performed by the S.S. Schleswig, a weekly service during Ja- nuary, February and March, and that the twin- screw express steamer Hohenzollern has been selected to complete the sailings of the S.S. Schleswig. The S.S. Hohenzollern will leave Alexandria for the first time on the 18th Jan- uary, and continue to call as announced in the Company's advertisement.

div.head: THE STATISTICAL BUREAU.
div.p: In the Budget for 1905 L.E. 5,000 is set apart for the creation of a Bureau of Agricul- tural Statistics, mention of which has already been made in our columns.

div.head: MEHKEMEH SHARIEH.
div.p: The Committee charged with the revision of the Code of Procedure of the Mehkemeh Sharieh will be composed of the following members, under the presidency of Sheikh Mohamed Abdou: The Grand Ulema of Alexandria, Sheikh Abu Khatwa, Sheikh Abd- el-Kerim Suleiman, and Sheikh Abd-el-Rahman Foda.

div.head: POST OFFICE INSPECTION.
div.p: The Postmaster General has gone for a trip up the Nile for the purpose of visiting the various post offices as far as Assouan. Saba Pasha will be back at Alexandria about the 20th inst.

div.head: ARMY LECTURES.
div.p: The following is a list of the lectures to be given in Cairo for the benefit of members of the Army of Occupation, with the dates and
lecturers:-

Dec. 12. Organization, etc., of the R.A.M.C. in war. Major J. F. Donegan, R.A.M.C. Dec. 19. Organisation of the A.S. C. and Supply in War. Major A. E. Delavoye, A.S.C. Dec. 27. Experiences with the Pekin Relief Force. Lt. Col. G. F. W. St. John, R.A.
Jan. 3. A campaign of the American War. Captain G. B. Byrne, 2nd Bn. Rifle Brigade. Jan. 9. Organization of lines of Communica- tions in War. Colonel C. Rawnsley, D.S.O.,
A.S.C.
Jan. 16. Savage Warfare. Colonel L. B.
Friend, R.E. Jan. 28. Field Fortification. Captain W. H. Rotheram, R.E.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: The P. & O. 8. N. Company's Steam Yach "VECTIS," 6,000 tons, will leave Alexandria on Friday, the 9th and 80th of December for MARSEILLES, taking Firet Saloon Passengers only, at the usual mail 24854-6

div.head: A NEW SCHOOL.
div.p: Kishk Bey, a wealthy resident in Zifta, is building a large school 10,000 metres in area and covering in all 70 feddans of land, which he has endowed for the purpose. It is expected that 70 per cent. of the children attending the school will be free pupils, and that it will be opened in about three months' time.
1 THE MOUTRAN OF COPTS.

This dignitary spent last week in Mit Ghamr. The rich Copts in the town have endowed about fifty feddans of land to be under his control, in order to enlarge their school and make it equal to the provincial Government schools.

div.head: NEW METHOD OF MARRIAGE.
div.p: A Moslem teacher in Zifta wished to marry one of his pupils, aged 16. The parents refused to permit the marriage to take place. Last week, he asked the girl to become his wife in the presence of the pupils and three other persons. The girl accepted his offer. By this means he became her husband and is recognised as such in Sharaa, in spite of the opposition of her parents.

div.head: WET WEATHER.
div.p: Much rain fell here yesterday and again to- day. Several houses have fallen in and many people have been prevented from going to their work.

div.head: THE ABSENCE OF THE TANZIM.
div.p: Everybody knows from the papers that we have a Tanzim, but as no one ever visits the place that is all the knowledge of the Depart- ment that we possess. No Tanzim and no Municipality! The town is surrounded with dirty pools of water. It contains many dirty houses, the post office is a small, inconvenient place, and the railway station, is along distance off.
Prices of commodities are very high. Mutton is P.T. 4 and beef P.T. 3 per pound. Fish is P.T. 8 per oke.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Sailor Prince arrived in Manchester from Alexandria on Tuesday with general cargo, &c.
The S.S. Castillian Prinee, from Antwerp, left Middlesbrough on Monday, with general cargo, &c., for Malta and Alexandria.
The Ellerman S.S. City of Cambridge sailed from Malta yesterday evening, and is expected to reach Alexandria on Saturday morning with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

div.head: OBITUARY.
div.p: MRS. W. J. WILSON.

The death of Mrs. W. J. Wilson, which occurred in Cairo yesterday, has evoked con- siderable sympathy among the members of the British colony at Alexandria, of which she was one of the oldest and most respected members. The deceased had been in good health until a very short time ago, when an attack of rheumatism set up a cardiac com- plaint to which she succumbed. Mrs. Wilson was the wife of the late Mr. W. J. Wilson, formerly of the firm of Behrend and Wilson, and in later years Egyptian correspondent of The Times. She was a resident here for about 35 years and was loved and esteemed by a very large circle of friends.
The burial of the deceased will take place to-morrow morning at 10 o'clock at the British Protestant Cemetery, Alexandria. Friends are requested to accept this as an invitation.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit within certain necessary limite-free discussion.
IS IT IDRIS BEY RAGHEB?

TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Sir, I noticed a letter under the above title in yesterday's Gazette, and as a Britisher I must strongly protest against the insinuations conveyed by it. The name of Idris Bey Ragheb is well and honourably known in Freemasonry and I cannot and will not believe I that he in any way countenances or upholds the attacks alluded to. I will venture to state that, assuming the newspaper in question has been attacking prominent Englishmen in Egypt, the attacks cannot be in any way inspired by Idris Bey Ragheb. He bears too high a name and is too much respected in England to lend his influence to any attacks on well-known Anglo-Egyptians. I can only assume therefore that "Enquirer" is actuated by malevolent feelings towards the highest native Freemason in Egypt, for up to now Idris Bey Ragheb has never shown himself an Anglophobe, and he would be the last native in the world to associate himself with newspaper campaigns against individual Englishmen in Egypt.
I am, etc.,
div.note: [We notice that, in to day's issue of the Cairo newspaper which has distinguished itself of late by its attacks on Sir Elwin Palmer and others, the fact that Idris Bey Ragheb is finan- cially interest in the organ in question is acknowledged to be correct. ED. E. G.]

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL.
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the see, Central position. Under English management, 81-11-904

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: More than one paper sees in the withdrawal of the 20th Hussars, a battery of Artillery, and the 2nd Battalion Highland Light Infantry from Egypt, the impending evacuation of that country by Great Britain and the return of the country to its state prior to 1881. This, how- ever, is going a bit too far yet. Great Britain has poured out blood and treasure like water to hold Egypt and to restore the Sudan, and it is not at all likely that she will withdraw from its control.

Brevet-Colonel C. Fergusson, D.S.O., Grena dier Guards, who lately returned home from Egypt (where he was employed as Adjutant General of the Egyptian Army at Cairo), to take up the duties of second in command of the 2nd Battalion at Windsor, has been selected for the command of the 3rd Battalion at Aldershot, in succession to Lieutenant-Colonel the Hon. J. G. St. Aubyn. Colonel Fergusson's many friends in Egypt will be glad to hear of his impending promotion.

Captain C. E. Birch, Royal Berkshire Regi- ment, recently employed as a District Com- missioner in the Sierra Leone Protectorate, has been placed on half-pay owing to ill- health, contracted on the West Coast.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Archduke Ludwig-Salvator of Austria will spend some of the winter months at his villa in Ramleh.

The Earl of Londesborough and Lord Chol mondeley arrive in Cairo to-day. The Countess of Londesborough and Lady Irene Denison are expected in Cairo in a month's time. They will remain in Egypt for the rest of the winter and will make a trip up the Nile.
The latest issue of the African World contains an excellent portrait of Mr. Carl Meyer, managing director of the National Bank of Egypt.

Mr. Adrian Leroux, manager of the Société Générale des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte, Chevalier of the Legion of Honour, Deputy of the French Nation at Cairo, arrived at Alexandria from Europe yesterday by the Messageries Maritimes steamer.
Messrs. Grenfell and Hunt are staying at the Hotel du Nil, Cairo.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: COUR D'APPEL MIXTE
JURISPRUDENCE MIXTH SUR UNE QUESTION D'ACTUALITE.
Actions Possessoires.

L'appel interjeté par Burbulia frères contre le jugement du Tribunal Sommaire du 21 Novembre 1903, qui les déboutait de leur action en réintégrande contre le Gou- vernement à la suite des faits de déposses- sion violente dont ils ont été l'objet a éé rejeté.

MM. Burbulia frères munis d'un acte d'achat s'étaient installés sur 2,000 fed- dans sis à Kamba (Béhéra) espérant pou voir y demeurer assez longtemps pour être en mesure d'exercer efficacement une ac- tion possessoire ou d'invoquer la prescrip- tion en cas d'expulsion tardive. Mais ils en ont été chassés violemment par les agents du Gouvernement qui ont brûlé leur kiosque. Le Tribunal d'abord et la Cour ensuite ont approuvé la conduite du Gouvernement .L'offre de prouver, au mo- yen de témoins complaisants, une posses- sion remontent à 18 mois, ainsi que l'exis- tence de canaux et de culture d'orge n'a pas été prise en considération, et a été déclarée inadmissible.

En somme la décision prise en l'appel est conforme à la jurisprudence de la Cour qui a toujours refusé le caractère d'acte de possession pouvant donner lieu à une action en réintégrande, à une détention résultant d'un fait furtif et qui n'aurait par consé- quent rien de commun avec une possession naturelle
(Bulletin T.D. Vo Actions possessoires, No 116 et tome XVI p. 2861).
Voici le texte de l'arrêt :-
La Cour,

Atenda que si le premier juge, se livrant d'ailleurs à une erreur matérielle et dans ane considération superflue qui n'a pu avoir aucune influence sur le mérite de sa décision, semble s'être attaché à tort à la durée de la possession en matière de ré- intégrande, il n'en a pas moins établi les conditions juridiques.

Qu'il est vrai que la loi, s'inspirant da principe que nul ne doit se faire justice par lui-même, a réservé à tout possesseur, victime d'une spoliation brutale, de se faire avant tout, réintégrer dans la dite pos- Bession.

Mais qu'il ne peut user de ce droit que pour autant qu'il justifie d'une possession paisible, publique et non équivoque, quelle que d'ailleurs sit pu en être la darée, pourvu qu'elle ait existé au moment de la dépossession.

Que s'il résulte, comme en l'espèce, que la dite possession, a été la conséquence 'd'une entreprise furtive ou clandestine pour se créer, à la faveur d'une détention dolosive, un titre à la prescription, l'on ne Baurait invoquer l'action en réintégrande dont l'objet est d'empêcter précisément des pratiques de cette nature, et d'assurer au détenteur actuel la possession paisible dont ila pu être brutalement privé.
Attendu, dans cet ordre d'idées, que la nature de l'entreprise tentée par Bour- boulis frères, semble résulter amplement des pièges du dossier.

Que, sans que l'on ait à rechercher la force probante des pièces ou enquêtes ad- ministratives quand le douvernement est Ini-même en cause, il est loisible d'en dé- gager les éléments qui en sont indé. pendants.

Que c'est ainsi que Botouros Hanna et Costi constantin ont déclaré, par devant le maoun de la Moudirieh, avoir été envoyés par les frères Barbulis d'Alexandrie, pour prendre consignation des deux milles fed- dans dont s'agit.

Que cette déclaration, émanant des pré- posés mêmes des frères Barbulia, rappro- chée des termes de l'acte introductif d'ins- tance, et dans lequal ces derniers se bor- nent à déduire le fait de la possession, uniquement de leur qualité de propriétaires, semblerait en exclare toute prise de pos- Bession de la part des appelants.

Qu'il est vrai que ces derniers concluent en voie sabsidiaire, à une enquête. Mais que le seul fait qui ait une certaine pertinence consiste en ce que les appelants prétendent établir d'avoir procédé, en 1902, à une culture chetoui (orge) sur les dites terres; mais que ce fait, en en admettant même l'existence, peut avoir été la consé- quence d'une toléranc de la part du Goa-
vernement.

Qu'il n'établit point, en toute hypothèse, la continuité de la possession jusqu'au mo- ment de l'attitude reprochée aux autorités. Qu'enfin l'invraisemblance même des autres chefs de preuve, et leur contra- avec les haut relevés enlèvent tout caractère de pertinence et d'admissibilité à l'enquête réclamée. Qu'ainsi le Gouvernement en repoussant une entreprise clandestine et en détruisant une construction d'ailleurs sans impor- fanc, et élevée furtivement sur son do- mai e, n'a fait qu'aser d'un droit que l'on De saurait fai contester. Per ces motifa: Bomb Barbalia frères de leur appel. En conséquence; confirme le jugement attaqué. Condamne enda les appelants à tous les
TRIBUNAL COMMERCIAL MIXTE D'ALEXAND BIE
Bank of Egypt contre Vve A. Minotto et Edward A. Minotto
La Bank of Egypt réclamait de la damer Vve A. Minotto et solidairement de M. Edward A. Minotto le paiement d'une somme de P.T. 645,081, montant d'une dette de feu A. Minotto, capitalisée au 7 0/0.
La dame Vve Minotto arguait de l'in- compétence du tribunal de commerce à statuer dans cette affaire et contestait au surplus le compte courant présenté par la Banque et le taux de l'intérêt 7 0/0.
Quant à M. A. Minotto, il plaidait pour son compte une fin de non-recevoir,attenda que la dame Vve Minotto était la seule héritière de son mari.

Le tribunal de commerce vient, par son jugement de ce matin, de statuer sa propre compétence dans cette affaire en se basant sur le fait que feu M. Alexandre Miaotto était commerçant et que son compte- courant avec la Banque relève donc du tribunal de commerce, s'agissant en la matière d'un compte entre deux commer- çants et la mort du débiteur ne pouvant pas changer la nature de sa dette.

Sur la mise en cause de M. Edward A. Minotto, le tribunal prononce qu'elle est mal fondée puisque sa mère est restée la seule héritière de feu A. Minotto et doit être seule, par conséquent, à en supporter les dettes.

La compétence du tribunal ainsi admise et l'obligation de M. Edward Minotto écartée, le tribunal aborde la question de la capitalisation de la dette et juge que cette capitalisation a cessé d'exister à partir de la mort da débiteur en 1900, en même temps que l'existence du compte-courant. A dater par conséquent de 1900 la dame Vve A. Minotto n'a plus qu'à payer l'inté- rêt de la dette au taux de 7 0/0. Ce taux étant celui convenu avec le défant et, la dame n'apportant pas de preuve suffisante qu'il ait été ultérieurement modifié, reste done valable. Quant au redressement du compte-courant, le tribunal estime qu'il ne suffit pas d'apporter de vagues assertions pour l'obtenir, mais qu'il faut articuler des faits précis sur lesquels les juges puissent se baser.
Voici le dispositif du jugement:

Jugeant publiquement et contradictoire- ment, le ministè.e public entenda, rejetant toutes fins et conclusions plus amples ou contraires, se déclare compétent; met hors de cause Edward A. Minotto. Dit pour droit que la dame Vve A. Minotto est tenue au paiement de la succession telle qu'elle résulte du compte courant présenté, sauf pour ce qui concerne la capitalisation mensuelle d'intérêt que le tribunal écarte, condamne la Dame Vve A. Minotto es-nom et es q. à tous les frais de l'instance, des honoraires de l'avocat de la Bank of Egypt taxés à P.T. 300, sauf les frais faits à l'en- contre de Edward A. Minotto qui resteront à la charge de la Bank demanderesse, les honoraires de l'avocat de ce défendeur taxés à P.T. 300 aussi.
M. Rovigo contre Chitty Bey.

Nous avons reproduit le jugement da tribunal mixte de commerce qui condam- nait M. Rovigo, pour tentative de contre- bande, au paiement du double des droits d'entrée et à la confiscation de sa moto- oyolette. M. Rovigo ayant depuis consenti à se désister de son appel, un accord amiable est intervenu entre les parties. L'administration des douanes lui a restitué sa motocyclette.
L'intéressante question de droit concer- nant l'introduction d'objets usagés n'a done pu être tranchée par la Cour. Ce sera pour une prochaine occasion.
COUR D'APPEL MIXTE

L'audience de ce matin de la Cour d'Ap- pel Mixte a été levée de bonne heure pour permettre aux conseillers de se rendre au Caire pour les fêtes du Baïcam. Pour le même motif l'audience de demain de la 2me chambre de la Cour d'Appel n'aura pas lieu.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demi)

A la suite d'une légère reprise sur les cotons et en raison de la baisse trop accentuée de ces. derniers jours, les cours sont remontés un peu de matin. De 23-3/16 hier après-midi la Banque Nationale a repris à 23 7/16, l'Agricole de 10 3/8 à 10 9/16 et la Salt & Soda de 38/6 à 40/6. La Delta Land remonte également à 3 15116 les Eaux du Caire à 1095, la Delta Light à 14 7/8, et les Privilégiées Tramways à 145. Par contre la baisse s'accentue pour la Ban- que d'Athènes à 130, pour la Nungovich à 9 5/16, pour les Dividendes Tramways à 360, pour la Wardan à 8, et pour la Brasserie des Pyramides à 125.
Demain, à l'occasion du Baïram, le marché
est fermé.

div.head: NEW YORK COTTON MARKET.
div.p: Telegram received to-day from New York by Messrs. Andres, Chawarby & Co., of Alexandria. The chances are in favor of market dec-ining, in consequence of favorable repors by Agricultura Bureau and of large orop estimates Both Price and Neill's estimates are nearer Thirteen than Twelve Million bales. However we look for ad ocossional resotion. Alexandria, 7th December.

div.head: Délégation Municipale
div.p: (Communication officielle)
La Délégation Munisipale s'est réunie le 5 décembre 1904, à 9 h. p.m sous la prési- dence de M. Amb. A. Ralli.
Présents: MM Mansour boy Youssef, Mob. bey Said, E. Stross, Soliman bey Abani, membres, W. P. Chataway, admi- nistrateur, I. Sedky, secrétaire.

Communication est doanée d'un projet tendant au percement de la rue Bahary bey jusqu'à la marine. Cette question étant lié, à celle du prolongement de la rue Bidi Metwalli, la Délégation la renvoie pour une étude d'ensemble au Comité spécial, chargé de l'examen de ces propositions.
La Délégation dé.ide de renouveler avec la Cairo Sewage Transport la fourniture de chars de vidanges.

Sur la proposition de l'inspecteur sani- taire, et considérant que la poate a disparu de la ville, la délégation, de l'avis conforme de la direction générale des services eani taires du Caire, décide d'autoriser la ré ouverture du commerce des abiffons.

La Délégation prend connaissance d'une lettre de la société archéologique informanty que, sur sa proposition, la Direction géné- rale du service des antiquités a bien voulu céder à la ville d'Alexandria 2 obélisques parmi ceux qui gisent dans les ruines de San. La Délégation décile de remercier les donateurs et de soumettre cette lettre à la Commission Municipale pour acn infor- mation.
La Délégation décido l'installation de quelques lampes électriques et lanternes à gaz dans quelques rues de la ville et d Ramleh.

Elle regrette de ne pouvoir faire droit à une requête tendant à choisir un autre em- placement que celui déjà arrêté, dans le square près de la Bourse, pour l'installation du nouveau chalet de nécessité, adjagé à Ramadan Youssef.
La Délégation prend note d'un état des recettes et dépenses de la Municipalité à fin novembre 1904. Les recettes se sont élevées L.E. 175.885.

Elle émet un échange d'idées au suj des propositions budgétaires de M. l'Admi nistrateur pour l'aonée 1905, et se réserve de les examiner en détail dans de. pro- chaines réunious après les fêtes de Baïcam, réanione fixé 8 aux 13 et 14 décembre 1904.
La séance est levée à minuit et demie.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL ETHIOPIAN RAILWAY TRUST AND CONSTRUCTION COMPANY, LD.
div.p: The following is the report of the directors, to be submitted at the second Annual General Meeting to be held on the 19th inst.:-

The Directors have pleasure in submitting the balance sheet of the company as at 27th September, 1904, with profit and loss account for the two years ending that date, showing a profit of £8,907 18s. 7d. After deducting the balance shown by the previous account and the additional remuneration voted to the directors on 27th February, 1903, there remains a sum of £2,067 6s. 1d. to be carried forward. This result has been arrived at by taking the assets of the company at their original cost, which is well within the market value. They are glad to be able to state that negotiations are now proceeding with a view to the neutralisation of Abyssinia and the internationalisation of the Imperial Ethiopian Railway, which will have an important influence on the company's large interests in that railway. These negotiations were not sufficiently defined to make it desir- able to call the shareholders together at an earlier date. The trust company has now increased its holding of Ethiopian Railway bonds to about 20,000 Three per Cent.Obligations of fcs. 500 each, whilst the holding in ordinary shares has been reduced by 4,000. In addition, your com. pany has acquired, among other assets, certain rights with regard to the future extension of the line, the prolongation of which to Addis Abeba, the capital of the Emperor Menelik's dominions, now appears, in one way or another, assured. Particulars with regard to the business and prospects of the Railway Company are to be found in the last report issued by that company, a reprint of which is hereto annexed. The succeeding report has also been delayed for reasons con- nected with the negotiations above mentioned. The line is now working regularly between Djibouti and Diré Daouah, a distance 310 kilometres, and the traffic receipts are creasing, the returns for the first six months of 1904 being 4,871 tons as compared with 895 tons for the corresponding months of last ear, and 2,008 tons for the year preceding. tom Diré Daouah a wagon road has been structed towards Harrar, the commercial centre of Abyssinia, which is thus placed in direct communication with the Red Sea. During the past year negotiations were in progress between the Emperor Menelik and the chair- an of the Railway Company, having for their nect a further agreement with respect to extension of the line from the rail-head Diré Daouah to Addis Abeba, in accordance the original objects of the company and the terms of the concession granted in 1904. at in the meantime the Board, whilst loyally porting the French Government and the ....perial Ethiopian Railway Company in their endeavours to push forward the railway, have ver lost sight of the desirability of harmo- nising English and French commercial interests, and indeed those of all the nations concerned in the Ethiopian railway. The directors are pleased to be able to state that their views are now regarded with favour by the Governments interested, as well as by the Emperor Menelik himself, and they believe that an arrangement can shortly be arrived at which will recognise and guarantee the independence of Abyssinia, and harmonise the commercial policies of all the nations concerned in the railway, thus removing the possibility of any serious conflict of interests hereafter. In this way it is also believed that the finance of the extension o the line to Addis Abeba can be most econo- mically carried out, whilst the internation- alisation of the Ethiopian Railway would, it is needless to point out, be of great benefit to all stockholders alike. The annexed maps show alternative plans for carrying into effect a scheme of internationalisation. From plan No. 1 it is seen that the French and British ports of Djibouti and Berbera would have equal rights, and the railway would start on an international basis from Diré Daouah or Urrar to Addis Abeba. Under plan No. 2,
Co

uti would become a free port for Abyssi- nia, French commercial interests in French maliland being secured, and the line would internationalised throughout to Addis da. As the adoption of plan No. 1 would il the construction of another line in So- is iland, for which there may not be sufficient nic, plan No. 2 would appear to be the more pedient. It is anticipated that the tax on goods going in and out of Abyssinia, which Railway Company have already the right collect under the terms of their concession, ild serve as a satisfactory guarantee of the ital necessary for the various extensions. Directors have established an agency at dis Abeba, under the management of Captain R. Brian England and M. Leopold ljer, who have most zealously watched the any's interests in that country, and have opportunity, owing to their good relations All concerned in Abyssinia, of entering fresh business there under the most Favourable circumstances. In view of the growing importance of Djibouti, and of the probability of its becoming a free port and the future harbour to which all the traffic of Abyssinia will be directed, the Board decided to acquire important interests at that port, comprising town sites, houses, &c., which should increase substantially in value when the internationalisation of the railway is completed.

In accordance with the provisions of the Companies Act, 1900, we certify that all our requirements as auditors have been complied with, and we report to the share- holders that we have audited the above Balance Sheet and the Profit and Loss account. We are informed that the assign- ment of the Djibouti Lands and Buildings (the consideration for which has not been handed over pending registration of the assign- ment by the French authorities at Djibouti) is in process of registration. In our opinion such Balance Sheet and Profit and Loss account are properly drawn up so as to exhibit a true and correct view of the state of the company's affairs as shewn by the books of the company.
COOPER BROTHERS & Co.,
(Chartered Accountants) Auditors.
London, 24th November, 1904.

div.head: FOOTBALL.
div.p: SAINT ANDREW'S VERSUS DRUMMERS ROYAL BERKSHIRES.

Saint Andrews again travelled on Saturday to Mustapha, where they were to have been opposed by the Drummers' eleven, but, on account of absence in Cairo of several of the Drummers' team, the inclusion of some of the company players was necessary. Saint Andrew's, showed changes from last week, but as the teams lined up both sides looked like render ing a good account of themselves. Bright won the toss and elected to play against the wind, which was blowing strongly from end to end of the field. It was soon evident that the wind would trouble the players not a little. The homesters were the first to make their presence felt. Edmunds had the opening try, but he sent the ball over the bar. The Saints' for wards at length got an innings, and Gough and Wythe had to exercise all their well- known abilities to keep them from getting within shooting range. After a few profitless runs by the home forwards the Saints again got away, Fitzgerald getting possession and passing to Clark, who was well placed for Booring. Wythe, however, intercepted and again play was transferred to Saint Andrew's territory. Many fine openings were spoiled by poor shooting and Curtis was kept busy with goal kicks. Smith tried Curtis with a shot from long range but the "Long' un" had no difficulty in clearing. A series of corners well placed by Hunt troubled the Saints' defence greatly, but both Dawson and Atkin were playing a safe game, and play was ultimately transferred to midfield. Fitzgerald and Clark were exhibiting some magnificentwing play. Their work was pretty and effective and they caused Campkin and Wythe no end of anxiety. Despite all efforts, however, the Saints could not get within range of Carbine. The backs were clearing well, but their placing was defective, the wind no doubt upsetting their judgment. Dawson and Atkin were having a lot of work to do, but they managed to repulse the attacks of the forwards with invariable success. They were ably assisted by the middle line, Nixon in particular being very prominent. Success at last came in the way of the homesters, Grimmer getting in a low raking shot which Cartis saved well and cleared, but Carter got the ball close in, and had it in the net before Curtis had had time to recover. This success on the part of the homesters acted as an incentive to their ac- complishing greater things, but the defence opposed to them fairly rose to the occasion. The Saints' left wing now got away, Jones centreing to Cowie, who tested Carbine with one of his rockets. The interval arrived with Saint Andrew's pressing and the score-Drum- mers 1-Saint Andrew's O.

From the restart the Saints took matters in hand and with the wind now at their backs they strove manfully to equalise. Gough and Wythe, however, came to the rescue and sent them back empty-handed. The Saints' forwards were now showing much better combination than they did in the first half, the right wing particularly troubling the defence. The Saints were pressing hard and looked like getting the equaliser. It was rather a surprise, however, to all when Atkin put his team level from a well-placed shot from midfield. Carbine, instead of handling, as he had time to do, kicked out, and the ball swerved from his foot into the net. Stimulated by this success the Saints con- tinued to press hard, but the home defence was not idle by any means. The homesters, however, could seldom get away and the Saints were evidently bent on taking the lead. This they got through Nixon who gave Carbine no chance to save. Later Jones had a chance to further add to the score but he put past. Right on to the close the Saints continued the pressure but no further scoring took place and Saint Andrew's retired victors by two goals to one.

It must be said that both teams played very pretty football. The players could hardly be criticised individually, as all played in combin- ed fashion. The wind was to a very great extent responsible for the poor shooting, up- setting the judgment of all. But for this factor in the game both custodians would have got much more work to do. The following were
the teams:
Drummers:-
Carbine, Gough, Wythe, Grimmer, Barnett, Campkin, Hunt, Handerly, Carter, Smith and Edmunds.
Saint Andrew's:Curtis, Dawson, Atkin, Sweet, Nixon, Bright, Fitzgerald, Clark, Cowie, Jones and Tulloch.
